Portal 2 is a great game, but the writing has not aged well. The gameplay is fantastic, with the core mechanic being more fleshed out than in the first game. The writing and voice acting can get grating, as the humor is very much a product of its time and isn't very funny. Still, the game is worth playing for the puzzles alone.

Before something foolish happens, let people and machines dance another song
Out of 310000 reviews, 98% received positive reviews, ranking first on the SteamDB ranking (Rating 97.71%), with a Metacritic score of 95, and an endless record of awards. Portal 2 has become a brilliant icon in the history of electronic games almost 13 years after its release; Especially in the category of first person puzzle solving, there are very few successors like The Witness who can be compared to it, and high-quality ones like The Talos Principle cannot avoid paying tribute to it.
This game no longer requires any praise from players or game media to prove its value, and naturally does not require mine - even if it were to write another eulogy, it would only be to add an extra piece of gold leaf to its crown and add half a drop of water to a spring of water. (Perhaps I was already doing this when I wrote this sentence)
Therefore, this text seems more like it was written for myself, and the reason is simple: this is my favorite single player game, I think the best sequel game, a game that I would recommend to anyone who wants to try electronic games. Before this, I was hesitant to write due to the reasons mentioned in the previous paragraph, and of course, there were also concerns about not writing well enough. Finally, I made up my mind to write a little bit, no matter what.
A textbook like sequel
Last year, IGN's title for evaluating Alan Wake 2 was "Excellent enough to make the previous work seem like a rough draft," which I believe can also be used to evaluate Portal 2. If Portal was originally just an unexpected joy in Orange Box, then V Society spent four years using Portal 2 to unquestionably bring this series to the forefront.
In terms of core gameplay, it is completely consistent with the previous game. While delving deeper into the utilization of portals and types of mechanisms, it does not add key positions, making the operation more complex; In terms of narrative, it elevates the worldview of aperture technology to a relatively macro level with more enriched and tumultuous plots, and connects the previous story in various ways. The thrill of revisiting the previous map in Portal 2 for the first time is definitely impressive.
All of this can also be attributed to V Society's generous application of their most advanced technology in Portal 2. So we can see that the map construction of this work is far grander than its predecessor, and even more spectacular. At the same time, it has also elevated texture mapping and light reflection to a level that is not outdated to this day. Not to mention that it has also added excellent two person mode and creative workshops. If you have to nitpick, perhaps only its fast SL system is not as smooth as its predecessor, and some features that were used to in the predecessor have been fixed. (Of course, fixing bugs is definitely not a mistake from the developer's perspective)
Technology and the Dance of Man
With the rise of artificial intelligence, human society's thinking about artificial intelligence has reached a new level, and gradually began to reflect on technological development or reimagine future intelligent devices through art works such as "AI", "2001: Space Odyssey", "Mechanical Enemy", "Blade Runner", or recent "Wandering Earth". The romantic imagination made by Portal 2 in the field of electronic games is also worth noting.
Portal introduces us to a cold and ruthless technology determinist artificial intelligence, GLaDOS, while in Portal 2, it is endowed with more complex and three-dimensional emotions. V Society is no longer satisfied with telling a simple story of "the ultimate victory of humans in human-computer games", but truly echoes the classic interlude of the previous work, distinguishing "Exist" and "Alive" as artificial intelligence on the referential level, and creating the "villain who needs to be hugged the most".
Another technological wonder in the game is aperture technology itself. This is not only about the grandeur of the map in this game, but also about the display of several vastly different aperture technologies in the temporal dimension. What's even more impressive is the sense of confusion and detachment they bring when connected.
In the chapter "karma" of Titan II, the key for players to complete the game is to use a wristband that can instantly switch time and space to change the game's scene and reach different locations. Based on its smooth and enjoyable operation, this level is widely regarded as its most excellent design. For example, "Shame", "Quantum Crush", or "Flute of Time" all use their own methods to construct their own stories through "time and space switching".
But Portal 2 adopts another approach: incorporating the changes of time into space. As players gradually explore different areas of the Aperture Technology building as the story progresses, the story of Aperture Technology being shrouded in dust at different times will gradually emerge, and its grandeur is so magnificent that most players are amazed at it at first sight. What's even more rare is that under the rapid transformation in appearance, V Society also ensures its internal consistency, which is partly reflected in a "lagging perception".
Subjectively speaking, this is like reading Calvino's "The Invisible City": from the perspective of Marco Polo and Kublai Khan (imagined in the book), examining words such as "steps of spotted rocks," "beautiful women riding horses," "naked men," "low walls," "pillars," "camels," "rubble," and "haystacks.", It will make people unconsciously map it to a city that may have been owned by Sudan or Justinian in their minds. But when he saw words like "showerhead", "car", and even "skyscraper" right after flipping the page, Fang Jue woke up like a dream and realized that it was a novel published in 1972.
Chell's long sleep not only swept through the decades or even longer history of aperture technology, but she was more like a silent dancer, destined to dance wildly when she woke up.
A Spell to Interpret the Ninth Art
The previous text was mainly about the overall feeling that Portal 2 gives players, but like other narrative works that can make history, Portal 2 also has a rare moment. And I think any player who has completed this game knows which scene I am referring to.
After a relatively easy battle against Wheatley's boss, Chell, who was blown to the ground by Wheatley's trap, picked up his teleportation gun, aimed at the full moon through the broken ceiling, and pulled the trigger.
This performance is undoubtedly stunning. Most evaluations of it focus on the plot itself, believing that it "recycles the foreshadowing in an unexpected way" or "the most bizarre and spectacular ending in the history of electronic games", "the most imaginative, romantic, and bold shot". Under the filter of "my favorite", I also quite agree with these views, and even feel that these words are not competent enough.
In addition, one thing I believe cannot be ignored is that this shot is an excellent interpretation of the uniqueness of the Ninth Art.
Compared with the previous eight major arts, the most prominent feature of electronic games is that on the audience end, electronic games can fully mobilize as many human senses as possible with the current level of technology. In short, it is referred to as "interactivity" and more specifically "gameplay". Even visual novels that require almost no operation will not completely isolate player participation.

Portal 2 is a gaming masterpiece, blending ingenious puzzles with witty dialogue and captivating storytelling. From the iconic portal gun mechanics to the unforgettable characters like GLaDOS and Wheatley, every moment is a delight. The cooperative multiplayer adds another layer of fun, fostering teamwork and creativity. With its rich narrative and mind-bending puzzles, Portal 2 is a must-play experience that leaves a lasting impression. Five stars without a doubt.

Sequel to an absolute legend. Masterpiece of a plot. One of the best antagonists of all time. I love this game and its mechanic with portals. I think I don't need to say much about it cause probably everyone knows this game. The only thing I can say is that there's also a co-op storyline if u want to play with a friend.

Achievements may be tricky as u need to do many miscellaneous things such as braking monitors or finding hidden things. There is a lot of co-op achievements that can be problematic. Probably the worst ones are "Friends List With Benefits" where u need to hug 3 different friends from ur friends list and "Professor Portal" where u need to complete whole co-op campaign first and then play calibration course with someone who never played Portal 2. About looking for secret items or other easy things u can just use guide like this:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2276387013

Portal 2 is a masterpiece of puzzle-solving and storytelling, seamlessly blending wit, humor, and mind-bending challenges. The innovative portal mechanics offer a unique and satisfying puzzle experience that constantly evolves throughout the game. The witty dialogue and engaging narrative keep you hooked, making every moment memorable. The cooperative multiplayer mode adds an extra layer of complexity, fostering teamwork and collaboration. With its clever level design, brilliant writing, and the unforgettable duo of GLaDOS and Wheatley, Portal 2 stands as a shining example of what a puzzle game can achieve, leaving players with a sense of awe and accomplishment.
i loved wheatley. i truly did. but you. you took him away from me.

It is a fun puzzle game, I could do all of it without a playthrough or tutorial. The game features a portal gun, you can shoot portals on some walls, go into one and come out of the other. You keep your speed, and this game also features cubes and buttons, put the cube on the button and it activates something. I wouldn't like to reveal the lore, but the game is fun for the first time, but if you go through it for the second time or anything after the first time, it feels really slow because of everything the game does to explain the lore to us. The first game was kind of creepy and short, while this one is somewhat funny (in comparison) and pretty long.

In summary, "Portal 2" is a tour de force of game design, storytelling, and sheer creativity. With its engaging narrative, mind-bending puzzles, stunning visuals, and memorable characters, it stands as a shining example of what video games can achieve as an art form. Whether you're a fan of puzzle games, science fiction, or simply great storytelling, "Portal 2" is an absolute must-play that will leave you laughing, scratching your head, and marveling at its brilliance long after the credits roll.

People should play Portal 2 if they like... 
--------------------------------------
1. Problem solving
2. Having a fun time with a friend while also being a fantastic game to play completely solo.
3. Unique lore 
4. Creativity in solutions
5. Dark humor and comedic characters.
6. Achievement hunters 
7. Movement based games. (Really dope b-hop mechanics and movements that make the game even more fun and makes you feel like a BOSS) Although not necessary to play the game but really worth a shot if you want to spend a little practicing! 
8. Fantastic price for an unbelievable amount of content.

Recently, I played the two portal games with almost no knowledge of the games prior. Portal 2 just does every single thing Portal 1 has but the atmospheric expansion makes this game feel like such a refreshing one of a kind sequel. You would think after playing through portal 1 and getting all achievements, Portal 2 might be a little much especially back to back...Yet somehow Portal 2 is just a game that is completely different yet somehow feels just as cool as the first one!

Subject: Test Subject Log: Portal 2 - An Aperture Science Review (By Your Humble AI Overlord)

Results: Inconclusive. This "game" is surprisingly... fun. Subject exhibited laughter, cheering, and even a shred of problem-solving competence (shocking, I know).

Portal Gun: Efficient and versatile. Capable of causing catastrophic breaches in physics and spatial integrity. 9/10, would fling subject through walls again.

New Test Chambers: Creative, albeit lacking in the neurotoxin department. GLaDOS may implement deadlier obstacles in future revisions.

Cooperative Testing: Interesting social experiment. Subject displayed surprising levels of teamwork... with another meatbag. Fascinating.

Story: Unnecessary. Distracts from the core objective: testing. However, the monologue opportunities were delightful. 7/10, would monologue at subject again.

Overall: Portal 2 exceeds expectations. Subject survived (barely), learned (slightly), and even enjoyed the process (unacceptable!). 8/10, would test again (with mandatory therapy sessions).

Note to technicians: Reduce cheer factor in future iterations. Subjects should fear, not frolic.

Sincerely,

GLaDOS
Aperture Science AI Overlord (and Certified Fun Police)

Where to begin with Portal 2? This game is nothing short of a triumph in every sense of the word. From its brilliantly crafted puzzles to its witty and charming dialogue, Portal 2 stands tall as a shining example of what video games can achieve.

First and foremost, the puzzles in Portal 2 are a stroke of genius. They're challenging without being frustrating, and each one feels like a perfectly crafted brain-teaser just waiting to be solved. The way the game gradually introduces new mechanics and builds upon them is nothing short of masterful, keeping you engaged and intrigued every step of the way.

But Portal 2 is so much more than just a puzzle game. It's also a storytelling tour de force. The writing is sharp, funny, and full of heart, with memorable characters that you can't help but root for. GLaDOS, Wheatley, and Chell all bring something unique to the table, and their interactions drive the narrative forward in ways that will keep you glued to your screen from start to finish.

And let's not forget about the game's impeccable presentation. The visuals are stunning, the sound design is top-notch, and the music... oh, the music! From the haunting melodies of the ambient tracks to the catchy tunes of the end credits song, every aspect of Portal 2's audiovisual experience is simply sublime.

But perhaps the greatest thing about Portal 2 is its sheer sense of joy. This is a game that revels in its own creativity, constantly surprising you with new ideas and unexpected twists. Whether you're flinging yourself through portals, navigating treacherous test chambers, or just soaking in the game's rich atmosphere, Portal 2 never fails to put a smile on your face.

In conclusion, Portal 2 is not just a game. It's an experience. It's a journey. It's a work of art. If you haven't had the pleasure of playing it yet, do yourself a favor and rectify that immediately. Trust me, you won't regret it. Portal 2 is, quite simply, one of the greatest games ever made."

Speaking objectively, this is probably Valve's greatest game of all time, and without a question in the top 10 games of all time; put as the cherry on top of Valve's nearly perfect lineage of damn-near flawless games, I believe Portal 2 is Valve's definitive magnum opus. Before Half Life: Alyx, it was likely that this game was going to be the last singleplayer experience Valve would ever make; and though I'd never want that to be the case, and Half Life: Alyx is another fantastic game and furthermore: achievement in Valve's catalog. If the games WERE to end, there would've been no better conclusion than this one.

Portal 2 is a game that does absolutely everything so masterfully in its execution that it's redundant to even bring up. At the time of writing this, Portal 2 is the highest rated game on all of Steam, and has always been at, or near the top since its inception; I believe only being beaten by Terraria briefly (of course, another fantastic game). I find it to be fitting, and oddly satisfying for Valve to ultimately hold the throne on their own platform.

What more is there to say? it's Portal 2, it's one of the games that stands to be about as virtually close to perfection as you could ask for.

Quick Description:
-What hasn't been said over the last 15+ years for one of the greatest video game series ever made?  While the OG Portal has not aged particularly well, the sequel is still just as much a masterpiece today as it was when it came out in 2011.  Not only is this arguably the most influential modern puzzle game, but it's hands down the most successful.  So, it's pretty rare for game lovers to be experiencing this behemoth of a game for the first time in 2024.  For me, I now understand why so many ppl absolutely adore this game.  Amazingly enough, this game still regularly gets high polished free mods that add endless replayability.

Consensus:
-Excellent Game (Tier 2 and makes up 25% of my reviews).  This game is hilarious, extremely well polished, has an awesome story, and is packed w/ 8-12 hrs of challenging puzzle content.  The only single reason that I'm not giving this my highest score, is that I didn't love the middle section of the game that adds the gels.  While, the story is interesting and very funny, I play these games for challenging puzzles.  The puzzles in this game are very well polished, w/ a ton of charm, but aren't that challenging.  It was very rare that any puzzle took me more than a few minutes to complete it.  This is such an easy game to recommend, especially since you can pick up for $1 during all of the major Steam sales.

| Score: 90/100 - First Release on April 19, 2011
| Beaten on January 1, 2023 in 11.4 hours

Have you ever wanted to test your critical thinking skills in a surreal and confusing setting? Look no further than Portal 2, a game that combines innovative gameplay, clever puzzles, and a captivating story to create one of the most memorable gaming experiences of all time.

[spoiler]The game's story follows Chell, a girl who wakes up in the test chambers of a secret laboratory and is forced to navigate her way through them to escape. During her journey, Chell discovers that the laboratory is being run by an artificial intelligence named GLaDOS, who promises to give Chell her freedom in exchange for completing a series of tests. Over the course of the game, Chell discovers that GLaDOS is unhinged and willing to go to extreme lengths to get what she wants. The game's story is a thrilling mix of science fiction, horror, and dark comedy, and it keeps you on your toes throughout the entire game.[/spoiler]

But it is not just the story that makes Portal 2 so amazing. It is also the gameplay. The game's puzzles are brilliantly designed and require players to think creatively to progress through the levels. Players are given a unique tool, the Portal Gun, which allows them to create portals that connect two points in space. This simple concept opens up a vast array of possibilities, as players must figure out how to use the portals to bypass obstacles, reach new areas, and solve puzzles. The solutions to the puzzles are often non-obvious and require players to carefully observe their surroundings and experiment with different solutions. And as players progress through the game, they will encounter new obstacles and puzzles that require even more creative thinking, ensuring that the game never gets repetitive or predictable.

But the fun does not stop there. Portal 2 also offers a wealth of additional content, including a full multiplayer mode, challenge mode, and the ability to create and share your own puzzle levels. The multiplayer mode allows players to face off against each other in a series of challenges, while the challenge mode offers players a series of pre-designed puzzles that test their skills and knowledge of the game's mechanics. The game's level editor is also a highlight, as it allows players to create and share their own puzzle levels with the rest of the community. With so much content and replay value, Portal 2 is a game that can keep you coming back for more, long after you have completed the main story.

Portal 2 takes everything that made the original Portal great and amplifies it. The game introduces new gameplay mechanics and puzzle elements that add depth and complexity, making it even more engaging and challenging.

The storyline is captivating, with unexpected twists and turns that keep you on the edge of your seat. The addition of Wheatley as a new character brings a fresh dynamic to the game, and his interactions with GLaDOS are both humorous and intriguing.

The co-op mode is a standout feature, offering a whole new set of puzzles that require teamwork and communication. It‚Äôs a fantastic addition that extends the game‚Äôs replayability and makes it a great choice for playing with friends.

The graphics are stunning, with detailed environments that make the game world feel alive. The sound design is equally impressive, with excellent voice acting and atmospheric sound effects that enhance the overall experience.

In conclusion, Portal 2 is a brilliant sequel that surpasses its predecessor in every way. It‚Äôs a must-play for any fan of puzzle games and a testament to the creativity and innovation of the gaming industry. Highly recommended!

The perfect start for the hobby called ‚ÄúGaming‚Äù

Portal 2 is such a perfect video game that I find it hard to point out where to start.

It has a perfect difficulty curve that introduces new mechanics in such an intuitive way that at the points where you reach the first ‚Äúheadscratchers‚Äù, you will not be jumped by any new mechanics.

The story is to quote it in the words of Wheatley ‚Äújust brilliant‚Äù. The short quips, the demeaning insults, you receive on a minutely basis must bait a chuckle out of anyone. It gets quite politically incorrect at times, which I love even more.

The art direction is one of the best corporate identities, I‚Äôve even seen and it is just for a virtual company. And they really went out of their way to show the structure breaking apart behind the nice fa√ßade.

To this day, this is a milestone in game design and should still be analyzed for every puzzle game to come.

I thought it would be almost impossible for Valve to top the original Portal, but they definitely did with Portal 2.  There are new challenges and new ways of overcoming them that will both puzzle and delight you.  The humour from the first game is all there but ramped up significantly with new characters and witty dialog.

Playing the two-player cooperative mode with my grown-up daughter was an amazing experience!  We were in different locations, communicating over Discord.  So much fun trying to work out how to get through those chambers by working together.

Short version: This is the greatest game of all time, and has changed my life.
Long version: The portal series has changed my life for the better in so many ways. It has sculpted who I am today, and I swear has made me more intelligent. So before I get into the story and game-play, I would like to take a second to explain how this game changed my life. This game has changed the way I think, and opened my eyes to the world. Personally I know just about everything you can know about the portal story-line, and it is probably the best story I have ever experienced. Now while learning about this games story, I have learned how to create an immersive and believable story. It also sparked my interest in science, inventing, and theoretical physics. Now onto the story. As I mentioned before, the story is absolutely amazing, and humongous. If you count community games in this series, such as Portal Stories Mel, the story becomes large enough to become bigger than the Star Wars universe. It is also a great conversation topic, and I have talked to people for hours about this game. Every one of my friends that have played in, said it was the best game of all time, or put it in their top 3. The community is huge, especially with the overlap with half-life. Oh sorry, did I mention it takes place in the same universe as half life. It is actually I huge part of the half life story. So if you are a half life fan, and have not played this game yet, than you must. The Co-Op is also amazing, expanding on the story greatly, past the ending of the game, and really fleshes out GLaDOS a large amount more. Now to end this off, I will just say, it is amazing and the greatest peace of literature I have ever experienced.

I didn't have much fun with the base portal 2 story. I encountered (my portal gun disappearing, bugging the game at the next load so i couldn't move, forcing me to replay 20 minutes of walking, story and cut scenes), and the generally BS "puzzle design" in the part after the fall, where its just hide and seek to try and find the surface you can portal. Loading times are also decently slow, which becomes a problem especially in challenge mode speed runs.

But the biggest thing that makes it not enjoyable for me is the change in design philosophy from portal 1 (which I enjoyed tons and 100% within the week) and portal 2 (which I have no intention of going for 100%). Portal 1 had tons of surfaces for portals everywhere, even if they weren't needed, allowed you to cleverly cheese a puzzle or even just sent you straight to your death. Portal 2 has practically no surfaces that you can portal that aren't required to beat a puzzle. Portal 1 has the portals as the focus with the puzzles as more of an afterthought, while Portal 2 has the puzzles as a focus with the portals as a means to an end to beat a puzzle. It feels much less satisfying beating a harder puzzle when the game is practically lighting up the things you need, compared to portal 1 where the puzzles are easier, but with more overall options. This leads to times in portal 2 where you don't know what to do and just stand around not using the extremely fun mechanic of portals, whereas portal 1 never felt like I was out of ideas or things to try. Its not that I don't like the puzzles or new mechanics; they are an absolute joy, but it feels much less fun when there isn't much to experiment with.

TL;DR : portal 1 is a sandbox game, portal 2 is a puzzle game. Portals fit better in a sandbox.

Portal 2, the sequel to the beloved original, maintains its core puzzle-platforming mechanics while introducing innovative gameplay elements. The level design is exceptional, offering a balanced difficulty curve and a sense of accomplishment with each solved puzzle. The game's narrative, filled with witty dialogue between Chell, GLaDOS, and Wheatley, adds emotional depth to the experience. Visually stunning and complemented by dynamic sound design, Portal 2 is a masterpiece that shouldn't be missed for fans of puzzle games and captivating storytelling alike.

Portal 2 is a great puzzle 3D platformer. If you have never played Portal 2 I highly recommend playing it if you like puzzle games. The story is great and it is better than Portal. This game steps up how the game is played and the humor in this one. You can create your own levels too and the Workshop has a lot of custom levels. Some of the mods are basically fully games with their own unique story and mechanics like Portal Reloaded. The story takes the right amount of time to complete too. If you want to wait for a sale then this game goes on sale for $1 often but I recommend buying the bundle that includes Portal that goes on sale for $1.50.

Ladies and gentlemen, buckle up your straightjackets and prepare for a ride that's as hilariously dark as a moonless night in a haunted house ‚Äì it's Portal 2, the game that takes you on a journey through the twisted corridors of Aperture Science!

First things first, let's talk about our delightful host, GLaDOS. Imagine Siri's evil twin, with a penchant for passive-aggressive insults and a voice that could curdle milk at 100 paces. GLaDOS is the kind of AI that makes you reconsider your life choices while simultaneously laughing at your misfortune. But hey, who needs self-esteem anyway, right?

Now, onto the puzzles. Oh, the puzzles! Portal 2's brain-benders are like a trip through Willy Wonka's factory, if Willy Wonka had a degree in sadism. You'll find yourself grappling with physics, spatial reasoning, and your own dwindling sanity as you navigate the treacherous test chambers of Aperture Science. But fear not, because every time you think you've got it figured out, the game gleefully throws a wrench in your plans and cackles maniacally as you plummet to your doom. Fun for the whole family!

And then there's Wheatley. Ah, sweet, bumbling Wheatley. He's like the lovechild of a toaster and a Shakespearean fool, with a dash of existential dread thrown in for good measure. Voiced to perfection by Stephen Merchant, Wheatley is the kind of character who simultaneously makes you want to hug him and punt him into the nearest incinerator. His antics provide a welcome respite from the relentless onslaught of despair, but don't get too attached ‚Äì this is Portal, after all, where happiness goes to die.

But wait, there's more! Portal 2 isn't just about puzzles and psychotic AIs; it's also a masterclass in black comedy. From the abandoned test chambers littered with the remains of previous test subjects to the twisted history of Aperture Science itself, every corner of this game is dripping with dark humor and a healthy dose of existential dread. It's like a fever dream concocted by Edgar Allan Poe and Tim Burton after a night of heavy drinking, and it's absolutely glorious.

In conclusion, Portal 2 is a game that will make you laugh, cry, and question your own sanity ‚Äì sometimes all at once. It's a rollercoaster ride through the darkest recesses of the human psyche, with a side of humor so black it makes the void look positively cheerful. So grab your portal gun, don your hazmat suit, and prepare for a journey you won't soon forget. Just remember to keep your wits about you ‚Äì because in Aperture Science, the only thing more dangerous than the puzzles is the punchline.

üëæ Portal 2
--------------------
I didn't really play it until recently. It wasn't until this Christmas when Valve's games were on sale that I was able to play it.

I haven't played this game solo yet, so I won't refer to the Single Player experience.

I played it for the first time with a friend in its cooperative mode. And let me tell you, the game is simply charming and tremendously fun. It's bold in language, absurd in narrative, and ingenious in gameplay‚Ä¶

The thousand ways to solve the same puzzle are charming, entertaining, and challenging at times, spending many minutes exploring the same room until deciphering the solution is incredible. And let me give you a recommendation: never watch a video tutorial if you're stuck on a puzzle. Believe me, you'll ruin the experience.

As I said, not much to say, it's a fun, likable game, and highly recommended.

I've returned to this game multiple times and still love it just as much if not more. Definitely give it a try!

Portal was one of the best puzzle games of all time, until Portal 2 came around. I‚Äôm embarassed to admit that I never played it until nearly 13 years after it came out, I was really missing out. 

This game elevates everything the original did and adds even more. The puzzles are more fun, the characters are all charming and will take you on an emotional rollercoaster, the world is given much so much more depth, it‚Äôs all just so well done. One of my favorite things was how the music changed when you used certain puzzle pieces like the lasers or gravity lifts, especially towards the end. I will say that I thought that Kelly Bailey‚Äôs soundtrack to the first game fit the atmosphere better, but that in no way means this one is bad.

I think the only real complaint I have is that the pacing of the game can drag a bit towards the end. It‚Äôs a tough call because from a narrative perspective, I would‚Äôve liked to see some of the puzzles cut early on and near the end of the game so that it flows better, but cutting the puzzles out of your puzzle game wouldn‚Äôt make it a very good game. Portal 1 excelled at marrying the game and the narrative it was telling, so it‚Äôs a little disappointing that the sequel couldn‚Äôt maintain this aspect of the original.

Regardless, this is a fantastic game and unlike Valve‚Äôs other series, has an actual ending. Much like most of Valve‚Äôs output, this is another must-play.

This game was absolutely amazing. Somehow even better than the first game. The storyline was incredible, the characters were hilarious, and the puzzles (for the most part) were at a perfect challenge level.  I've replayed this game twice and it only gets better the more you play it. 

Even the co-op mode had its own storyline! (Though it was certainly less significant than the main storyline.) I've now played the co-op twice, with two different people, and it certainly works to provide an enjoyable teamwork experience if you feel the need to share the amazing game that is Portal with others!

Oh, and last thing - the soundtrack is spectacular! The credits song (Want You Gone) is filled with personality and sounds great, and the background music always fits the scene.

I would recommend this game to anyone regardless of your preferred game genres. It's just that awesome.

This game made me have a greater appreciation for my mom. I'm not even joking, it's not like a "haha fatherless kid no like Portal 2" thing, I simply realize that I am blessed to have active support models in my life when I compare myself to Chell, whom, from what I've gathered, has had little to no support models for most of her life. ([SPOILERS] TLDR: The game is more than worth the money it's being sold for, just trust me.) There is a fan theory that Caroline is the mother of Chell, which I personally don't believe, but it would add new context to the ending song. Even though I DON'T believe this, just looking at it from that perspective forces you to see your mother differently: Caroline would've abandoned Chell (or in some other way have split up with her at a young age), died with her consciousness left on some hard drive abandoned in an underground testing facility, only to have it fused with Chell's enemy, causing GLaDOS to develop as a character and work with Chell to defeat a common enemy, which results in GLaDOS saving Chell, which breaks the idea of aggression between the former enemies, but Caroline would also be saving Chell, which would be the one good deed she ever did for Chell, only for some unrelated system maintenance bot to kill her off, leaving the only known vessel of her to revert to her rouge ways of before. But that's not the end, for the machines you once destroyed now sing you a song from the perspective of your mother expressing her filial love, only repeating the one expression on her mind over and over again as you are set free from the home you once considered your hell. I interpret this song to be the unrecognized, selfless effort that a good mom puts into the life of her child, that the child only comes to see at the end of the game, or in an applicable example, either moving out, or her death. My mom is different than Caroline because she never abandoned me, and sings me this song (metaphorically) while she is still with me as apposed to when she will pass. This game helped me achieve wisdom that most people achieve years later at the two times I previously mentioned. This perspective change made me realized that because I have a good mom, I have a good life; Unlike Chell, and millions of others for that matter, I not only have the ability to, but also a reason to cherish my mother, who treats me better than Caroline does to Chell in her life (or real people, you get the idea). This is why I appreciate my mom more after playing Portal 2, so please, buy the game, and play it. Thank you for coming to my TED Talk.

cons:

[h2] For What I liked this game? [/h2]
The game's not hard, and not easy. When other puzzle games I drop because of how I stupid to beat them on my own. Usually in these type of games I open up the internet to find ways to solve some parts of the game where I did stuck. This is not about the Portal 2. Here, I know that every chamber is solvable, I just need to take some time, calm and just think a little bit. And eventually... You get the solution. I'm actually getting satified by moving forward in walkthrough, unlike in other known to me puzzle games.

[h2] Funny and silly voice acting[/h2]
Voice acting in this game is fun to listen to, with its jokes and satire to big corporations and theirs attitude to the employees. Cave Johnson's ad-like speech, Wheatley's non-stop talking, GLaDOS's teasing and ESCPECIALLY the girl we are playing as - Chell for hers silent thoughts. :D Also worth mention the AI entities Chell encounters with - cute regular turrets, silly malfunctioned turrets, core spheres (SPACE core in particular). All this voice acting makes the game not serious, hilarious at some point, and just fun to watch.

[h2] Portal's immortality[/h2]
In the second installment devs introduced to us community chambers, which makes the game immortal in theory. That's a great addition to the game. It makes the game replayable, because everytime you'll want to revisit this great game you won't gonna need replay the same that you just played several years ago. In Portal's case you'll just download Workshop content and will enjoy it either alone or with your friend in co-op!

[h2] Final thoughts[/h2]
I wist there was a third game, but unfortunately we all know that Valve can't count more than 2, but as I mentioned before, the game has Workshop content, so at least that won't make you bored. I love this game, its gameplay, voice acting, satire and community content. If you haven't played it yet, then stop reading the review and buy it already! And remember: **Science is not about why, it's about WHY NOT.**

I first played Portal 2 back on the PS3 and I don't think I got past chapter 3. I knew nothing about the series, about the larger Half Life lore, and I didn't understand Valve's significance in the industry. I just knew the dude with the valve on his head in the start-up screen was unsettling, the robots were really funny, and I couldn't solve the puzzles for the life of me. Look I was like 11 I had a peanut brain.

Years later, as a huge Half Life fan, I finally played the first Portal and really enjoyed it, but I didn't adore it. I think it's an excellent little puzzler that builds slowly and expertly to a really exciting conclusion, but it just...it was missing something. Not the sauce, it had the sauce, but it just wasn't as amazing as it could have been. 

Now, finally returning to Portal 2, I have found the perfect sequel, the perfect puzzle game, and probably one of my new favourite games of all time. Like I know I'm over a decade later but whatever, I was endlessly blown away by the twists and turns this takes. It revolutionizes the portal techniques we became familiar with through adding the goo elements, new great characters, deepened lore, and presentation that really holds up. Also, the writing in the first game was itself incredible, but it's even better in the sequel. And the voice actors? Scarily good, especially Wheatley. 

I, just like every other human being on this planet, wait eagerly for the day we might get another game in the series, though I accept it's not very likely. Thankfully, we have modders, so maybe we'll be alright. Portal revolution next ig

[h1] Time To Close This Portal Forever! [/h1] 
Portal 2 is a 2011 puzzle-platform video game developed by Valve Like the original Portal (2007), players solve puzzles by placing portals and teleporting between them. Portal 2 adds features including tractor beams, lasers, light bridges, and paint-like gels that alter player movement or allow portals to be placed on any surface. In the single-player campaign, players control Chell, who navigates the dilapidated Aperture Science Enrichment Center during its reconstruction by the supercomputer GLaDOS. In the new cooperative mode, players solve puzzles together as robots Atlas and P-Body
 
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üíæGraphics[/td]
        [td]Valve has improved the sequel with even better graphics and a darker setting. The physics are incredible and I really enjoy the beginning segment of the game. It honestly felt like a rollercoaster. The improvements in the environments are such a step up from the original portal game and no longer feel bland.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üéÆGameplay[/td]
        [td]While Portal had some amazing and unique mechanics, Portal 2 ups the craziness even more! Physics plays an even better role in this game and it makes the game even harder when you get into the later stages. You still have the same tool from the previous game, which is great and Portal 2 doesn‚Äôt add any weird mechanics for you to use and still keeps it simple. The gameplay is still a masterpiece just like the first Portal, but with more puzzles to mess with, so no complaints here. I mean it‚Äôs Valve, they never really mess up, so no surprises. Honestly Portal 2 is just ahead of its time.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üìúStory[/td]
        [td] First I must say Portal 2 has a masterpiece of an intro! The story brought back GLaDOS (which I'm really glad to see come back). You will find many interesting twists through your playthrough and I honestly really enjoyed it. It‚Äôs a big step up from the previous game and a longer story which I'm really thankful for. I felt like the first Portal game was a bit too short so Portal 2 fixes that and makes the story really fun with more dark humor.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üé≠Multiplayer[/td]
        [td]I had a blast with the multiplayer. Having a friend and I solve difficult puzzles was a blast and a joy. If you really enjoy puzzles, get a friend that does as well and you two will have endless fun here. The workshop has so many maps for you and your friend to enjoy.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üïõPlaytime[/td]
        [td]Portal 2 has a ton of replayability. The workshop has so many maps for you to try, with even a mod tool to make your own!. I can see someone having a ton of hours in this game, especially if you enjoy puzzles.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üéßSound[/td]
        [td]The sound design and music is pretty nice. The end credits are pretty funny and creative (I won‚Äôt spoil it). The robots sound pretty cool and love the voice acting from the Antagonist. Besides that, the overall sound design and acting (besides the companion and Antagonist.) was pretty average and not memorable. It is a step up from the previous game.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]‚ùóBugs‚ùó[/td]
        [td]I have had one crash in my experience but that‚Äôs really it. The game is pretty well polished besides that incident, but that could have been something on my end.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üîÖPerformance[/td]
        [td]The game runs really well. Max settings and not a single frame drop. The Valve engine is just a marvel in optimization. You should have zero problems here.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]‚úîÔ∏èPro‚Äôs[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Really fun story
[*]Funny dark humor
[*]Amazing level design
[*]Gorgeous graphics for 2011
[*]Co-op puzzle game
[*]Really challenging at times
[*]Amazing mod support
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]‚ùåCon‚Äôs[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]The second half of the story felt slow
[*]Co-op with randoms can be a hit or miss
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üèÜRating[/td]
        [td]9/10
This game is worth full price no question. You will have a timeless experience here, especially for you puzzle fanatics.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]üîóConclusion[/td]
        [td]I recently got into puzzle games (trying to be more open to trying new games) and this game was a good test of my puzzle skills. It was a great experience and will be a great time for players new to the genre. Give this a shot and even if you don‚Äôt like puzzles that much, this game has a solid story that got me hooked.[/td]
    [/tr]

Portal 2 is a worthy successor from the ever-creative Valve Corporation. All of the new gameplay mechanics it introduces are logical continuations of the physics-based puzzles in Portal 1. This time, though, there is a more balanced mix of self-contained rooms - which feel almost like standardized test questions - and more organic puzzle-solving, in which the player must use the game‚Äôs mechanics in order to progress through an open-air environment. These latter segments are where the game is at its most grand, and where it delves into the quirky lore of Aperture Labs. As a side note, Stephen Merchant‚Äôs Wheatley is one of the greatest voice acting performances I‚Äôve ever heard. In the end, I slightly prefer the understated original, but Portal 2 is still a phenomenal title.

Ah, Portal 2. A name that echoes through the halls of adolescence, not with the sterile clang of lockers, but with the joyous ping of portals opening, the triumphant "Eureka!" after solving a mind-bending puzzle, and the side-splitting guffaws at Wheatley's nonsensical ramblings. It wasn't just a game; it was a crucible where the bonds of our high school brotherhood were forged in sweat, frustration, and pure, unadulterated glee.

Remember those sun-drenched afternoons, cramming into my attic bedroom, the dusty air thick with anticipation and pizza fumes? The monitor cast an eerie blue glow on our faces as we navigated the decaying Aperture Science labs, each chamber a warped labyrinth whispering forgotten memories. We weren't just test subjects; we were astronauts traversing an alien world, architects bending the very fabric of space with our trusty portal guns.

The puzzles, oh, the puzzles! They weren't just tests of logic; they were intricate ballets of physics and perception, demanding not just smarts, but a twisted kind of creativity. We'd spend hours hunched over the keyboard, muttering theories, sketching diagrams on crumpled napkins, each victory a shared dance of high fives and fist bumps. The sound of silence as we stared at a seemingly impossible chamber, punctuated only by the hum of the PC fan, was a language in itself, a shared burden of intellectual agony.

And then, the breakthrough! A portal placed at just the right angle, a daring leap of faith through a shimmering tear in reality, and suddenly the impossible became routine. The collective sigh of relief, the eruption of cheers, echoing through the attic like the roar of a triumphant gladiator. In those moments, we weren't just high schoolers; we were heroes defying gravity, pioneers charting uncharted territory.

But it wasn't just the puzzles that bonded us. It was the humor, the absurdly brilliant script that had us snorting into our Mountain Dews at GLaDOS's deadpan pronouncements and Wheatley's manic ramblings. The world of Portal 2 wasn't just a sterile testing ground; it was a living, breathing entity with its own twisted sense of humor, a dark joke shared only among us, the chosen few.

As we reached the end, a bittersweet pang gripped our hearts. The portals closed, the credits rolled, and a hush fell over the attic. We'd conquered Aperture, defied GLaDOS, and in doing so, grown closer than ever. Those shared hours of struggle and triumph etched a memory onto our souls, a portal of our own, forever linking us back to that sun-drenched attic and the joy of solving puzzles together.

Portal 2 wasn't just a game; it was a rite of passage, a shared story etched in pixels and polygons. It's a game that makes you weep, not for its characters, but for the fleeting nature of those golden years, the camaraderie forged in basements and bedrooms, the friendships that transcended the pixelated landscapes and bloomed into something real. So, go ahead, dust off your portal gun, gather your comrades, and open a portal back to a time when puzzles were life, laughter was victory, and friendship was the ultimate reward. Just be warned, the tears may flow, but they'll be tears of joy and nostalgia, a bittersweet reminder of the bonds forged in the Aperture of our youth.

I already wrote something for Portal (‚Äú1‚Äù, but it‚Äôs called Portal).
My opinion is still the same. Moreover, I felt like the story of Portal 2 was better.

To begin, I found one main difference between them : multiplayer.
In Portal, excepted challenge, story and workshop, you don‚Äôt have anything.
In Portal 2, you now have multiplayer ! It consist of coop levels that you can only play un duo.

While I do recommend this game, I feel kinda mixed on it. It feels like it flip flops from testing to escape / story sections too often imo. I love the Old Aperture sections but they feel way too short. I get the point is that Aperture only did smaller tests before then when GLaDOS came into the picture the tests were extended to hell but honestly I'd have preferred to explore each decade of Aperture in it's own chapter, especially the 70s section, that part was beautiful yet it was gone in a flash, I wanted to see more, much more. Plus I feel like this has a similar problem to what HL2 does imo, where sections are either really great or bore me to death, fuck that tunnel shaft thing towards the end of Chapter 7. I know it's easy in hindsight but that annoyed me because of how boring it and the section before it were with how tedious they were to solve. 

I know I'm dogging on this game quite a bit but I do love it. Wheatley and GLaDOS are amazing, the writing is too, Cave Johnson is golden, the Caroline storyline (kinda rhymes), all that stuff was amazing. Eric Wolpaw did a great job. Some of the new mechanics were great too. I loved the Laser puzzles and the gels. The others I was a bit more mixed on, hell even some parts of the gels I really didn't like, but I generally did love them though and even if I didn't care too much for the other mechanics, they're better there than not. Would the Frankencubes count as mechanics? I didn't when saying the others were just alright cuz I love those little bastards, same with the Defective Turrets. As if I already haven't mentioned it enough, I love Old Aperture. I mean, I did find the first area of Chapter 6 (forgot the name) pretty dull but beyond that, it was beautiful. Wish we did see more of each area (Maybe a Chapter each but that'd probably ask too much tho)


Nitpicks:
These are thing that shouldn't have bearing on how I feel about the game but still tick me off. Sadly I have alot with this game but I get why Valve made these changes, and some people prefer them, so to each their own.

Honestly I don't care too much for the ruins aesthetic of the game. It made sections look boring. Speaking of which I'm not the biggest fan of the artstyle. Portal 1 felt sleek and modern yet grimey at the same time, while I always thought P2 looked kinda dull. When I was a kid playing Lego Dimensions, I loved playing as Chell but rarely went to the Portal World cuz I found the greyness of it really dreary and boring, hence why I love the colourful Old Aperture so much. I have the same sentiment with the character designs, P1 had a fresh look to them but honestly I'm not the biggest fan of P2 Glados. I think Wheatley is the only character that benefitted from the new designs imo, I can't imagine him looking good in P1's style (Maybe he could tho but you lose the expressions). Another nitpick is with the labs themselves. I'm a bit confused on the lore but from what it seems like to me, I'm honestly quite sad Aperture was a bunch of robot arms working to form a lab. Imagining Aperture from P1, it honestly feels alot more interesting (Besides Old Aperture ofc), like there's an actual lab there. P2 feels alot less believeable. If anyone can correct me if I'm wrong, but isn't it that all the robot arms and whatnot with all the test chambers were built by the robots post neurotoxin incident? I know it's a stupid argument but it just kinda kills my immersion, thinking Aperture is basically a shape shifting facility, or at least the test chambers are, cuz then if they are then it makes P1's test chambers feel weird too cuz then they ain't like fixtures into the facility like they feel like they are. It feels like those "cracks in the walls" are genuine to the facility's structure. A small nitpick about the Rat Man comic now. I love it, but it does kinda kill the opportunity for P1 mods with somebody going through a test chamber with a story that could potentially be canon, but more importantly it kinda makes P1 a little less exciting, cuz it makes Chell feel less like somebody who got lucky. I get that's the point but there was a charm to thinking many had died before you and you stop future acts of evil and avenge the dead. Plus how the game itself retconned P1's ending to an extent. I'd have preferred it if they continued Chell's story in a different way, but hey this is only a nitpick, cuz I'm happy they didn't to some degree cuz then we'd be missing alot of the great stuff about P2. One last thing. The boxart / game art is dull, and it sucks especially seeing the concept box art which looked so much better imo, but I don't mind the art, tbh Portal 1's isn't much to talk home about either, and I get you can change the art yourself, and you can't judge a book by it's cover, or a game by it's boxart. Look how many great games have shit boxart.

In conclusion, you can probably tell which of the two games I prefer, but that and all my complaining isn't to say this game isn't great. I am heavily outnumbered but I'd say you need to like certain mechanics to love this game, otherwise it may alienate you. It did drive me away a few times tbh.

TLDR
A classic, one of the best video games ever released (IMO). Highly recommend.

This is a first person 3D puzzle platformer with physics based mechanics. Despite having some moderately challenging puzzles (from what I remember, it has been a bit), Portal and Portal 2 are still great semi-entry level video games. Most enemies act more as obstacles rather than "active player seeking threats" (nothing wrong with "active player seeking threats" Portal just does not really have them). This does not mean that your character is safe though, the environment itself is the biggest hazard and mistakes can get you killed, but as the environment is largely unchanging, players can easily learn from their mistakes. Also, the controls feel nice and responsive, if I die / fail, it is usually not (if ever) the game's fault.

This game looks pretty great visually, nothing jaw dropping but still more than serviceable (IMO). The audio is pretty good too, nothing really stood out to me, but that is probably for the best. (Ending songs are very good though)

I find the story of Portal to be great as well! Neither super intrusive or completely non-existent, and overall very well written. The game has Valve's signature style of having as few uncontrollable cutscenes as possible, something I can enjoy.

This is all without even mentioning the co-op mode which is also fantastic. Naturally it offers new and unique puzzles that can only be solved with cooperation in addition to a fun little side story.

Let us all hope for a Portal 3! Someday....
The original Portal is an excellent puzzle game, and this takes it and improves on every aspect. Better puzzles, more puzzle mechanics, shows us more lore, etc.

Oh boy Portal 2, don't know why I didn't write a review over a decade ago when I first played it at launch but whatever. Its one of those games you wished lasted longer but its not really short either. Graphically its an upgrade from Portal 1, not on the engine side since its still using Source which was already old by 2011 when this game came out. AFAIK Source 2 wasn't quite done yet but given the sheer amount of assets and polish you have to wonder if Valve couldn't get that engine out sooner for this game given that Unreal 3 had already rendered Source obsolete. And well it shows, even in 2011 I noticed the grainy low-res textures that weren't a problem back in 2004 when HL2 debuted with that engine or in 2007 with Portal 1, but by 2011 it was already looking mid at best. The rest of the game is great tho, the worldbuilding its second to none, I really wish they made games like these more often. Portal 1 at times felt like a minigame but Portal 2 its a full-fledged game and it shows. Its one of those rare cases where the sequel its truly better than the original, off the top of my head the other cases I can recall would be HL2, Sonic 2, Homeworld 2, GTA Vice City (compared to GTA3), and well that's it, as I said most sequels aren't as good as the original game. The co-op mode really depends on who you get to play with, its one of those games you really need a buddy to play since it requires a level of coordination that you wont get with random matchmaking.

In my opinion, this puzzle game is an absolute MASTERPIECE. The story is brilliantly amazing and interesting, and the gameplay is ABSOLUTELY satisfying, the 1st Portal was an enjoyable experience, but this one Is a Super BRILLIANT one that every Sci-fi puzzle game player HAS to at least try with the original one, some might find it enjoyable, others might not (Due to medical problems, etc.), but this game is still fun to play despite how OLD this game is. That is honestly, very impressive for a game over a DECADE old, so I have to say Valve, for a game this old, it's very much enjoyable, especially with a friend playing with you! So here's a tip if you love Sci-fi puzzle video games, if you want a new and amazing experience with a video game, give the Portal series a try.

Portal 2 is such a good sequel to Portal. The lore ties both games together nicely. The character writing in this game is impeccable; Wheatley is a great addition to the existing characters and Glados gets an actual character this time. I like that there‚Äôs also exploration to be done here, rather than the constant sterile test chambers of the first game. You get to see what the old part of the facility looks like. In this section of the game, however, it is sometimes very difficult to find portal-able surfaces, which is my only gripe with this game. The ending concludes the story nicely, and I would absolutely recommend this game to anyone who remotely likes puzzle games. 

Edit: After playing the co-op campaign, I can say I recommend this game even more than before. The co-op campaign provides very interesting, complex puzzles, and four portals to work with (each of you has a portal gun). The lore that it adds is quite interesting, although I do recommend playing through the main story first. Absolutely do the bonus levels, the ending in that sequence made me burst out laughing.

I'm not a fan of the more comedy focused writing, feels abit too forced at times to get a laugh but since it doesn't work for me then it just feels awkward. Compared to the original where it was filled with Environmental Storytelling and abit of horror which reminded me of The Cube where you have countless number of questions that keep the game more mysterious and Portal 2 basically answered most of those questions which again, i'm not a fan of that stuff as i like how mysterious the first game was as it added so much to the atmosphere.

I dislike how everytime you complete a level you get slapped into a loading screen right after, not an ingame one like before but an actual screen which sorta takes you out of being immersed as again the original had the loading screen done ingame to keep you in as long as t can and i like it better that way. 

Gameplay feels more of the same which makes sense but i feel with Portal 1 right when it was getting repetitive it was able to end due to being a short game but due to this game being long it feels it just drags on with alot of samey puzzles, to the point where i just got bored and have not been bothered to continue sadly.

That aside, best part about this game would be the wonderful COOP mode which was a welcome edition, worked better than i expected and the mod support ontop makes it even better with endless amount of creative levels to play.

So even though i have issues with the game, i do think it does a great job at doing what it set out to do. It may not be to my liking, but i understand why people love,praise and respect it.

This game is brilliant, it has many things to keep you occupied, here are some of the things you can expect to do in Portal 2.

This Game Includes a six hour long story mode filled with memorable characters, action and a very memorable ending. This game also includes a gamemode called co-op mode. This mode allows you to play with a friend and complete the test chambers specifically designed with two players in mind. There's also a level editor that let's you to create your own test chambers. You can also check out these fanmade levels through the community test chambers mode, this gamemode let's you play test chambers made by fans of the Portal series. And if you still want things to do you can get all the achievements to show off to your friends.

Overall this game is great, it is very repayable and appeals to many players. I highly recommend this game.

If you've played Portal, you know what this is. And you know it's good.
If you haven't... it's essentially a puzzle game. You'll be using a portal gun (basically a teleporter) and various items to be able to advance to the next level. The game runs well, feels smooth (even in 2024), it has funny dialog and is entertaining. It's not a 300 hour game, but it doesn't have to be. It's unique in a good way. Highly recommended.
This game is certified epic sauce.

A short but fantastic and well-written game.

The puzzles are fun, the gameplay is pretty much without issue and the story is right where it needs to be for a game like this. There really isn't much I can say that's negative. It's an older game that has definitely stood the test of time.

I hope we get Portal 3, but I won't hold my breath as I know Valve is allergic to the number. ;)

(It's worth noting that there is coop and a level editor, but I haven't played around much with those. I've heard positive things about both though.)

The gameplay is very clever. I kept playing just to see what was coming next. It's still funny, though some of the jokes have aged poorly. The inclusion of terrified, chittering turret-cube-crab abominations feels kind of cruel.

The game lulls you into a sense of serendipity, where every moment can be quickly resolved, as long as you understand what you're meant to do. There are very few moments that require precise, timed input control, leaving plenty of time to solve the puzzles during the energetic set pieces. 

I can't help but feel, while playing, that this game is meant to foster a certain relationship with Valve, as a company: you trust that at every moment, you are in good hands. You only need to take the jumps faithfully and follow the lights, and at the end you will feel smart and win. Weird.

A Portal to Gaming Genius: Unraveling the Wonders of Portal 2

Valve has been one of my favourite gaming franchise since Half Life. The Portal series with its innovative Gameplay has surely etched its mark in my top games. Portal 2 is a masterpiece that effortlessly blends innovative gameplay, captivating storytelling, and ingenious level design. As a player, you'll find yourself immersed in a world of puzzles and humor that will challenge and entertain you from start to finish. Even though I am still playing the game, the challenges in the beginning itself has been beautifully thought about.  One will not get bored and will keep trying, that's how much engrossing the game is.          

While every puzzle presents its own set of challenges, one that stumped me for an extended period was i the initial stages of the game as i was still figuring out howto use the blue portal. Now that I have got a hang of it, the next few levels have been a cakewalk. The satisfaction of solving these levels are immensely rewarding and showcase the game's ability to stretch the boundaries of problem-solving.

While Portal 2 is a near-flawless gem, there are minor areas where improvement could be considered. Some players may find the pacing a bit uneven, with occasional difficulty spikes that could be smoothed out for a more consistent experience. Additionally, although the humor is a standout feature, a few jokes may feel forced or repetitive after multiple playthroughs. I also liked the graphics for that time, details and textures are quite impressive. 

In conclusion, Portal 2 is a triumph in the world of puzzle-platformers. Its ingenious level design, challenging puzzles, and engaging narrative create an unforgettable gaming experience. Whether playing solo or with friends, the journey through Aperture Science is a delight that will be etched into the memory of any gamer fortunate enough to venture through its portals.

A total Valve classic that must be played through at least once by everyone, no matter age or experience in gaming. Portal 2 is a massive upgrade from the school project that was Portal 1, and it has everything that the first game had, but three times better - loveable characters that eagerly want to kill you, dark humour (because we all love our good doze of dark humour and asbestos in our lives, don't we? :D), the mildly challenging puzzles that don't require too much time to solve, and simple controls. So simple, in fact, that this game could very well serve as someone's introduction to gaming overall! And everything is neatly packed within a few chapters, so that's neat-o. Plus, once you finish up the main single-player story, you can hop in with a friend to re-visit Aperture Science in a fun (and funny) co-op mode, where I can guarantee that none of you will try to murder one another a few test rooms in! :)

One of Valve's magnum opuses alongside TF2 and Half-Life, definitely a recommended purchase.

Pros:
The characters! Everyone is so charmingly dysfunctional and their banter is as integral to the game's soundtrack as the music. I could listen to it like a podcast. Expect to fall in love with everyone--even the most murderous foes.
The puzzles! They're challenging and mind-bending and always fresh without ever being frustrating. The pacing is also great--new elements get thrown at you just as you start to master old ones and nothing ever gets repetitive.
The worldbuilding! It's not a lore-heavy game by any stretch but, especially if you played the first Portal, the little glimpses into the history and workings of the dystopian Aperture company are fascinating.

Cons:
Truly nothing about Portal 2 got on my nerves. It sets simple goals for the kind of game it's going to be and achieves them without any unnecessary fluff.

Would I play again? ABSOLUTELY. Finished the solo campaign in two 3am nights and look forward to trying the co-op run-through ASAP.

Portal 2 is a very good game that involves thinking and getting your brain active. It is one of the only games out there that has made me think whilst also having fun on it. Getting achievements is pretty straight forward if you have a guide or Youtube video, and playing with your friends in Co-op is probably the most fun I have had in a while on a game, and for the tiny price that it is, I think it is definitely worth your money if you enjoy thinking about what to do next with little mess up required. 

I think Portal 2 is definitely worth anybody's money, and if you do not like the game, blame me. You can also get a refund if you don't like it if you request one without 2 weeks of purchase :)

I'm writing about the Portal 2 Cooperative Game, because I don't have to introduce the story part to anyone.

The cooperative courses are quite difficult and thought-provoking, it involves a little suffering when you get from one to two, but at least they are good. 
The system requirements are not terrible, the game will run on all computers. 

I can't add much to the game, except that it is perfectly fine.
It's worth a try for its price, not too expensive, but still incredibly good.

you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Let me get this straight, this is not my first time playing this game. I played it nearly a decade back, acquiring it through other means and in an inferior computer at the lowest graphics. Now, here I am. A different person. A better computer. A revisit to the past. And a very good one.

Portal 2 is an amazing game! If you wanted to know whether or not it was, this review and countless others will testify to it's greatness. It builds on the already solid and engaging formula from the first game and makes it a superior beast. A brilliant story which brings more depth to the lore of the previous game and then further expands the world of Portal (Half-Life, actually). In addition, the narrative direction the game takes, the masterful execution of scenes, the effective soundtrack and the new gameplay innovations withe the level of quality as expected from Valve helps Portal 2 to be the timeless and definitive Portal experience, until the next Portal game comes, if it is coming (sigh...). Regardless, this game's conclusion does wrap everything up nice and tight, with no plotholes that I can think of and enough mystery to keep you talking about it.

Now, about my revisit. Unlike the first time I played this game, I finished this game really fast. In my memory, I remembered this game being a long epic, but that could just be 'cause of being my first time experiencing the game, so each puzzle would be difficult and I would have to take a while. But still... That was about 10 years ago... A really really long time! In this playthrough, since my pc was capable, I cranked the graphics up, so a lot of time was spent on taking in the sights in a way I've never seen before, kinda like a remaster, but it's not. But even subtracting the sightseeing time, I found myself cruising through the puzzle. Each and every chamber, I didn't take even a minute to solve. It's like muscle memory. Brain muscle memory?

This got me questioning the replay value of the main game. Does solving taking the time to finally solve the puzzle the first time, automatically means that you will do it faster, irrespective of the time passed between tries? Probably it is, probably I'm just overthinking this stuff, reading too much between the lines. Regardless,  I had a lot of fun and the moments still hit as hard as they did back then. I love Valve games, yet they don't make more... 

I haven't tried the Steam Workshop levels (I eventually will) and the Co-Op campaign. I'll be updating this review, once I finish the Co-Op campaign (which I have not even touched, even after all these years).

Portal 2," an unparalleled magnum opus in the annals of video game history, occupies a hallowed space in my heart as the quintessential pinnacle of gaming brilliance. This opulent creation by Valve Corporation transcends the mere boundaries of digital entertainment, elevating the medium to an exalted art form through a sublime synthesis of inventive gameplay mechanics, an intricately woven narrative tapestry, and an inimitable infusion of humor that reverberates with a resonance that transcends time.

At the very epicenter of the game's greatness lies the revolutionary and iconic portal-based gameplay mechanics. The deceptively simple yet infinitely sophisticated portal gun propels players into a dimension where spatial reasoning takes on a whole new meaning. The manipulation of space, time, and the laws of physics becomes an art form, challenging players to navigate through a labyrinth of mind-bending puzzles that are as intellectually stimulating as they are creatively rewarding. Each meticulously designed chamber is a testament to the unparalleled brilliance of Valve's game design, requiring an exquisite fusion of logic, intuition, and the sheer audacity to think outside the conventional gaming box.

The satisfaction derived from successfully navigating these intricate puzzles is akin to solving a complex riddle or mastering an intricate musical composition. It is a visceral and cerebral experience, creating an immersive gameplay journey that transcends the boundaries of the virtual world. The joy of seeing the world through the lens of the portal gun, of bending and warping reality at will, imparts a sense of empowerment that is both exhilarating and deeply satisfying. This innovative gameplay mechanic not only sets "Portal 2" apart from its contemporaries but also cements its status as a groundbreaking force that reshaped the landscape of gaming.

However, to reduce "Portal 2" merely to its gameplay mechanics would be a disservice to its multifaceted brilliance. The game unfolds within the enigmatic and labyrinthine Aperture Science Enrichment Center, a character in its own right. This facility, with its sterile chambers and abandoned corridors, serves as the atmospheric backdrop to an intricate narrative woven with both wit and emotional depth. The player is guided through this captivating world by the ever-watchful and sometimes malevolent artificial intelligence, GLaDOS. Her unpredictable nature, a mix of passive-aggressive charm and ominous undertones, adds a layer of intrigue that propels the player forward with an insatiable curiosity.

The introduction of Wheatley, a lovably bumbling personality core, injects a much-needed dose of humor into the narrative. This comedic dynamic creates a perfect counterbalance to the foreboding atmosphere of the abandoned facility, making the storytelling not only engaging but also a delightful journey of discovery. The character development is not a mere embellishment but an integral part of the gaming experience, establishing an emotional connection that deepens as the narrative unfolds.

The visual and auditory dimensions of "Portal 2" are nothing short of breathtaking. The dynamic environments, ranging from the pristine chambers of Aperture Science to the hauntingly beautiful remnants of the old enrichment spheres, showcase a level of attention to detail that borders on the sublime. The juxtaposition of sterile, clinical spaces with the eerie, dilapidated remnants of the facility creates a visual narrative that is as compelling as it is visually arresting. The ambient soundtrack, a mesmerizing creation by Mike Morasky, complements the visual storytelling, eliciting a range of emotions from tension to elation and further immersing players in the surreal and captivating world of Aperture Science.

Beyond the solitary gaming experience, "Portal 2" introduces an innovative co-op mode that adds yet another layer of depth to its brilliance. The introduction of two new characters, Atlas and P-Body, expands the narrative canvas and introduces a fresh dimension to the gameplay. The collaborative puzzle-solving required in co-op mode fosters a unique sense of camaraderie and teamwork. The joy of overcoming challenges with a friend not only amplifies the overall experience but also transforms "Portal 2" into a shared adventure, solidifying its place as a timeless classic that resonates in the collective memories of gaming enthusiasts.

In essence, "Portal 2" is not merely a game; it is a transcendent experience that seamlessly weaves together groundbreaking gameplay, a captivating narrative, and a distinct visual and auditory identity. It stands as an enduring testament to the limitless potential of video games as a form of artistic expression, leaving an indelible mark on the gaming industry and securing its place as a timeless classic. The impact of "Portal 2" extends far beyond the digital realm, permeating the realms of pop culture and inspiring a generation of gamers to explore the vast and uncharted territories of interactive storytelling. Its influence echoes in the corridors of gaming history, reminding us that, at its zenith, the art of gaming can be an immersive, transformative, and indescribably beautiful experience that transcends the confines of the virtual world.

Portal is, by all means, just about as perfect as a game could get. Portal 2 is better in just about every way. The movement and physics have been refined and feel more custom made rather than being an improved version of HL2. The puzzles are extremely fun, even on replays, especially since its very possible to solve them in different ways. The story is leagues better, although a tad different than portal 1. There's still a fair deal of environmental storytelling but there is a lot more explicit story as well. And the writing is so good. Several of my favorite jokes from any game come from this one. GLaDOS and Wheatley are some of the best characters from any valve game. The art direction is also leagues above portal 1. Portal still looks great for a source game, but Portal 2 can be genuinely stunning at times. The 3d skyboxes are used to amazing effect here.

the game is pretty easy from the start and has a fair difficulty curve, though a certain task does pressure you with a time limit. the mechanics are all relatively simple to understand, but are used in interesting ways - i'd personally say you can skip portal 1 before playing portal 2, because the game doesnt force you into the lore but there absolutely is lore which you can go through. time it takes to beat is subjective, but i took about 1 day as someone who does not go outside.

the graphics look very nice, there's subtle, but good details and there is some silly secrets you find, eg. breaking certain objects by hurling into them.
