[h2] Portal 2, THE definitive puzzle game [/h2]

   Along with Left 4 Dead 2, Portal 2 would mark with its launch the end of Valve's golden age in which titles were released with great frequency, and as a successor to Portal (2007) it put an end to this beautiful period of the best way possible, being full of good moments, surprises and a lot of quality.

   Released on April 19, 2011, Portal 2 is a puzzle and platform title, a direct continuation of Portal (2007), also set in the science fiction universe of Half-Life, which continues the story of the title using the same bases. in its mechanics and expanding them.

[b] Below, a list of positive and negative points experienced during my time playing and free of spoilers (do not consider this as an absolute truth, but as what it is, a simple opinion) [/b]

[h3] What did I like? [/h3]

üü©   [b] The Gameplay. [/b] It takes the foundations of portal (2007) and expands them without becoming overwhelming.

üü©   [b] The story. [/b] the title places a direct emphasis on the story, developing it really well from start to finish.

üü©   [b] The style. [/b] The perfectionist and minimalist style adapts to the events of the story brilliantly.

üü©   [b] The setting. [/b] greatly expands the possible ways to maintain that elegant but bleak balance of Portal (2007)

[h3] What did I NOT like? [/h3]
 
‚¨ú   [b] Nuh-uh. [/b] I didn't find anything that really bothered me.

[h3] What should I take into account when playing? [/h3]

‚ùï [b] It is Re-playable. [/b] It has access to the Steam Workshop, where you can use countless levels (and make your own)

‚ùï [b] Works based on Source. [/b] Every command you use in Half-Life 2 is fully functional here. (including weapons and characters)

‚ùï [b] It has Cooperative Multiplayer. [/b] Offers a separate campaign from the main one in which you and your friend can cooperate together to solve problems together.

[h3] Personal opinion. [/h3]

   Very personally I consider this one of the best titles of its kind, it takes the already (personal) perfection seen before in Portal (2007) and squeezes it to limits where you would think it is unnecessary, but instead creates a campaign worth remembering for a very long time.

After the first game, I thought how this game could be further developed in terms of story, but Portal 2 surprised me in this issue. The mechanics of the game have been greatly expanded with the speed and jumping gels added to the game, as well as the moon dust that allows you to open portals anywhere, and some levels have become quite challenging and creative with these new gel mechanics. If we look at the story, the story of the game includes a much expanded aperture science history and the topics we are curious about as characters. The only negative thing about the portal series for me is that if I didn't like puzzles and thinking that would challenge my brain, I definitely wouldn't be able to play this series.

Coming to the coop mode of the game, I found the story short and sweet as a side story. If you are with someone who is calm and good at fun puzzles and can handle this situation when you are tired and you cannot think of anything, the game is really fun.

TLDR: 5/5 (in 2023). The wit, charm, and tight mechanics of Portal 2 are untouched by time.

I was initially worried finally playing Portal 2 in late 2023, but my fears were quickly put to rest. Nearly 13 years have passed since this game's initial release, but its witty writing, impeccable comedic timing, and charming setting have held strong. For years, other games have attempted to pull off comedy the way that the original Portal did, and very few ever succeeded. Portal 2 keeps that legacy going. I played the game on a Steam Deck using an Xbox Series X controller and had no issues with that experience. The platforming feels just as smooth and tight as ever. Every time I missed a jump, fell to my death, etc. I knew it was entirely my fault, and that's exactly what I want in a platformer.

If I was forced levy a criticism against Portal 2, it would be that in a few instances, it doesn't communicate the rules of the world to the player as well as I might like. Different players have different thoughts on how forthcoming puzzle games should be with what is or is not impossible in the world. I personally like a game to tell me very clearly what the rules of the world are and leave all the challenge in the puzzle itself. There were a few puzzles in Portal 2 in which my first step to solving the puzzle was discovering a new rule. I'm pretty precious about my time, and that type of experience usually leaves me feeling like my time was wasted figuring out the rulebook rather than finding the solution to the puzzle. That said, this is a very forced criticism because I feel that the game is a nearly perfect game. (SPOILER WARNING) After all, would Portal lose its magic if it simply told players to [spoiler]create infinite portals to gain speed[/spoiler]? Maybe Valve knows what I want better than I do, in this case.

A Masterpiece of Puzzles and Humour - Portal 2 Deserves Every Ounce of Praise

I can confidently say that Portal 2 has not only secured a spot on my top ten games list but has also claimed a special place in my heart. This game is an absolute masterpiece, seamlessly blending mind-bending puzzles, a captivating narrative, and a unique sense of humour that keeps you grinning from start to finish.

First and foremost, the puzzle design in Portal 2 is unparalleled. The game challenges your intellect in ways that are both satisfying and utterly enjoyable. Each test chamber introduces new mechanics, ensuring that you are constantly on your toes and never settling into a repetitive rhythm. The gradual escalation of difficulty is handled with finesse, allowing players of all skill levels to enjoy the experience without feeling overwhelmed. Solving each puzzle feels like a triumph, and the satisfaction that comes with mastering the portal gun is unparalleled.

The narrative in Portal 2 is another standout feature. Valve has crafted a story-line that is not only engaging but also hilarious. The banter between GLaDOS and Wheatley is comedic gold, and the addition of new characters like Cave Johnson adds layers of depth to the game's lore. The way the narrative seamlessly weaves into the puzzle-solving experience is a testament to the developers' storytelling prowess.

Speaking of characters, the voice acting in Portal 2 is top-notch. Ellen McLain's reprisal of GLaDOS is nothing short of brilliant, and Stephen Merchant's portrayal of Wheatley is an absolute delight. The chemistry between the characters is so well-executed that it enhances the overall immersion of the game.

The level of polish in Portal 2 is commendable. The visuals are stunning, the soundtrack is atmospheric and fitting, and the overall attention to detail is evident in every corner of the game. The dynamic between the sterile test chambers and the dilapidated Aperture Science facility creates a captivating contrast that adds to the overall experience.

Moreover, the cooperative multiplayer mode is a stroke of genius. It not only extends the game's replay value but also introduces an entirely new dimension of teamwork and communication. Solving puzzles with a friend using the portal mechanics is an absolute blast and reinforces the game's reputation as a social and cooperative masterpiece.

In conclusion, Portal 2 is not just a game; it's an experience. It flawlessly combines challenging puzzles, a captivating narrative, and a unique sense of humour to create a gaming masterpiece that deserves all the praise it receives. If you haven't played Portal 2 yet, you're missing out on one of the finest gaming experiences available. It's a must-play that will undoubtedly stand the test of time.

After playing the original Portal and enjoying it a lot, I started playing this game not even knowing it had a story mode, and after getting all the achievements, I can confidently say this sequel improves and adds onto every aspect of the original. Whats even more amazing is that this game came out in 2011, as it was way ahead of its time.

The graphics and animations are amazing (Especially the animation the Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device has when it shoots out a portal). The story and characters are very intriguing and make you want to play to see how it ends (The ending is amazing, you wont forget it), the voice acting also adds a lot to it. The puzzles arent that hard if you play video games pretty often (I only looked up a guide for one small part) and the concept is extremely unique, it never gets repetitive as the game adds new features often. Definitely a game everyone should own (Considering both this game and the original are under 1 euro when on sale).

Overall, I loved playing this game, both alone and with my friends, itll be an experience Ill never forget.

This Game gets a 5/10 from me, read the full review here:

 This game has the dummest plot that I have ever seen in my experience of playing games. The first Portal game wasn't some kind of masterpiece, but at least it was an enjoyable puzzle game with a very small and simplistic story. The problem with the second Portal game is the fact that it tries to write a story, but it does so in the stupidest and goofiest way possible. The problems that bother me so much with the narrative are:
  -How is Chell still biologically alive if Portal 2 takes place 50,000 years after the events of the first game? Even more, how does she look young after being alive for that unbelievable life period? Those are question that the game is not even trying to answer.
  -The initially friendly character, Wheatley, becomes evil in the middle of the game out of nowhere due to how much power he receives by being transferred into GLaDOS's body, even doing a cartoonish villan laugh and also having evil red light below him.
  -Speaking of, the whole character of Wheatley was specifically designed to be the dummest moron in existence as a fast and stupid way to explain why he beams evil due to the huge power that he received, but the real reason why he is not only that dumb, but also why he exists at all is because he is just a quirky comic relief character that cracks jokes only becausr Valve wanted to hire a well known comedian such as Stephen Merchant to voice the character (something that makes the character out of place with the other robot characters because he is the only one whose voice sounds natural and not as a robotic A.I. voice).
  -The final confrontation with Wheatley ends with the failure of the protagonist to press the button that defeats Wheatley from the position of power that he has, by the area being blown away, but the Chell is still alive after such a massive explosion like that, and the other solution that remains is shooting to the fucking moon (because apparently the portal gun can shoot that fast, and its shot can go out of a planet with a high atmosphere, go through space, and land to Earth's natural satellite.) and the newly made portal starts absorbing Wheatley and Chell into space (even if she is alive without having oxygen and being dressed only in a tank top), but in the last minute Chell gets recovered by GLaDOS and Wheatley is let to float in space!
  -And the last, the story needing so hard to end with a quirky song by the Turrets for the gamers to say "Oh Ma GoD, This is so HolsOme!", even if it doesn't have that much sense, why is it here?
 As for the gameplay, it's fine. It surpasses the original on a technical level, I think. But for what cause? The gameplay is frequently interrupted by the story's narration, and that wouldn't be a problem if the story weren't so stupidly written. I will go and say that the original was small enough for what it was, and it should have instead given the new puzzles from the second game in a DLC or an update to the additional content for Portal 1. Really, the only thing that I actually adored was the song played on the radio called "Exile Vilify" by The Nation, but that's it; there's nothing in the game that I can truly call exelent. Even if I said what I said, that doesn't mean that it's objectively an awful game. You could probably love this game, and for fair reasons, it has qualities. But that will not change the fact that I have a lot of issues with it, and it's not at all my kind of game. In the end, you will probably enjoy it; who knows? But I know for a fact that I will never in my life replay it!

my satisfaction.

Aperture Science:
We do what we must
because we can
For the good of all of us.
Except the ones who are dead.

But there's no sense crying
over every mistake.

'til you run out of cake.
And the science gets done.
And you make a neat gun
for the people who are
still alive.

I'm being so sincere right now.
Even though you broke my heart,
and killed me.

And tore me to pieces.
And threw every piece into a fire.
As they burned it hurt because
I was so happy for you!

Now, these points of data
make a beautiful line.
And we're out of beta.
We're releasing on time!
So I'm glad I got burned!
Think of all the things we learned!
for the people who are
still alive.

Go ahead and leave me...

Maybe you'll find someone else
to help you.

when there's science to do!

it makes me glad I'm not you.

On the people who are
still alive.

still alive.

still alive.

Overall, incredibly highly recommended.

When you think of "The Greatest Game of All Time" you may think about Mario, Half-Life, Fire Emblem, Metal Gear, or something like that.
When most people think of Portal 2, they say "Oh, yeah, I remember it! The game's pretty cool!"

But in reality, Portal 2 is the only game ever made that doesn't have any flaws.
It has great story, pleasant graphics, amazing gameplay, can't offend anyone, funny jokes, awesome voice-acting (including dubs), an infinite amount of player-made levels for free. it's neither long nor short, and even has completely unique co-op if you have a friend or a loved one!

10/10 - Hidden gem that everyone heard of

[b]You need at least 200 IQ to play this game.[/b] I just can't describe how I love this game. It doesn't take so much time to finish the game (well, it depends on how good you are at solving the individual puzzles), though if you like challenges and completing achievements, then you will spend bunch of additional hours in this game. Story, atmosphere, soundtrack, graphics, mechanisms, simply everything perfectly fits together. If you enjoy playing with your friends, Portal 2 offers multiplayer levels as well. They are a bit harder and you literally need to cooperate together. Just give it a try. I promise you won't regret it.
This game definitely deserves a place among (my) top games of all time.

I simply cannot get enough of Portal 2. The graphics are beautiful and the puzzles get progressively more challenging but all the while, once you find the answer, you'll say "I should have seen that sooner!" Sometimes I play another run and have to work out the puzzle's answer again because I forget! But that's just a part of the fun. GLaDOS' witty commentary is nothing short of hilarious and Wheatley is... well, Wheatley. I simply love the game and I believe I am currently on my 7th+ run through. I've honestly lost count. Love the game, and would recommend it above all the others in my steam library!

What a game. Even though I've played through the single player campaign at least a dozen times, every time it ends I'm left speechless. This game perfects basically everything; The music, characters, story, atmosphere, humor, etc. The co-op campaign is also fantastic. (except for you, Art Therapy; I hate you.) Especially if you're on VC with your friends, it makes for hilarious moments that a lot of other games just don't do as well as Portal 2. Seriously, this really is a fantastic game (made in 2011, mind you) and I highly, HIGHLY recommend you play through the single player and multiplayer campaigns, it's so worth it.

Such a unique and artistic game. The concept is very unique and the puzzles are very fun to solve. They're challenging at first, but as you keep trying, you figure it out easily. I especially like the laser puzzles where you use the portals and a block to direct the laser to activate a door or platform. GLaDOS is a pretty fun and interesting villain and Wheatley is pretty funny. This is a nice breath of fresh air from Valve's usual shooters. Definitely one of the most creative games of all time.

Portal 2 is one of those very few prestigious games that everyone owes it themselves to play once. The original Portal was a brilliant but short experience with its length and ambition making it feel like a large scale Half Life 2 mod rather than its own game. What it did incredibly well were two things; it pioneered puzzle design in a 3D space with its portals and it nailed the context of being a pee-on test subject being toyed with by malevolent AI. Its narrative may have lightweight, but it was highly compelling for the 2 or so hours you'd spend in the test chambers and in the backrooms of Aperture Science.

Portal 2 blasts Portal 1 out of the water in just about everyway.

its narrative is longer, much deeper, and so much more entertaining. Glados gets reintroduced as the villain as Stephen Merchant's friendly bumbling Wheatley AI core tries to secure you an escape until he gets plugged into Glados' systems and tripping on power sends you and Glados into ruins of the original Aperture Facility. The first Act alone is about as long as Portal 1 was and serves to reacquaint you with the Portal gun, lasers, hard light, and gravity wells and to sorta show you what has happened in the 50 odd years you've been asleep (the Combine Invasion in Half Life and the teleportation of the Borealis being some such events).

Act 2 introduces gel based mechanics. Blue gel makes surfaces and items bouncy, oranges makes you move faster on a surface, and white gel turns a surface into a portalable surface. As you make your way through, you will be guided by recordings of Cave Johnson (JK Simmons doing a sciencey version of J Jonah Jameson) and his assistant Caroline, the personality basis for Glados, along with Glados themself. I won't say more from there, suffice to say the story is frequently hilarious, smart, and compelling.

Co-Op is brilliant as well, having its own sub-narrative featuring Glados after the end of the singleplayer game. Each Co-Op puzzle is challenging and rewarding and also just fun to play with a friend as you each mess with each other along the way.

Valve and their team knock it out of the park time and time again with another timeless classic gamers will remember for a very long time.

 The story is top tier and the test chambers are fun yet challenging. The dialogue, voice acting, and sound design are also amazing and give off a very retro arcade vibe.

 In chapter 6 when GLaDOS gets some...aesthetic changes I find myself wishing they gave her more voice lines and had her talk to you more since she becomes very "close" to you. Similar to the weapons that talk to you in High On Life.

I'm usually not one for puzzle games, but I really enjoyed this game and will be looking into some mods to see what the community has been cooking up.

Amazing game, was a huge fan of the first one with the Orange Box all those years ago. This game very much humbled me as a gamer. Much longer than the 1st game and much more difficult. My only regret is going online and watching guides to help me finish some of the harder levels as the buzz you get from solving a difficult puzzle yourself is quite something. Late to the party on this one as it was released around 12 years ago now but glad I could experience this masterpiece.

This is one of the greatest video games I have ever played. The story was amazing with a unique plot twist. The gameplay was outstanding with smooth controls and great design. After 9.6 hours I finished the campaign. There were only 2 chambers in the entire game that I needed to use a guide to figure out. The level design is puzzling without being unfair or too challenging. Just when the portal gun starts to get repetitive the game introduces new game mechanics that completely change the way you solve tests. I recommend everyone play this game especially at its low price point. It only costs $10 (USD) and is often on sale for $0.99. There is a new mod coming out for this game that will almost be like a portal 3. This game is so worth it and will always be worth it in my eyes. Its the only 10/10 game I have ever played.

To put it simply, Portal 2 is one of the best games ever created.

This game offers a story rich experience that does not interfere with people who just want to play for the puzzles. It also provides lots of replay ability as the workshop contains many fantastic maps created by other players. This game appeals to both casual and serious players as there is a vast speed running community. The game also contains lots of humour aspects, with Stephen Merchant's voice for Wheatley being a perfect fit for the role.

However, i have heard that Portal 2 can induce motion sickness, as you fly through the air in many sections of the game. so i would be cautious about this game if you are prone to motion sickness in games.

Overall, Portal 2 is a game i will continue to cherish for years, and i would highly recommend giving it a chance as it may surprise you.

There are 3 acts of this game. I really enjoyed the first act, like the environment and story is great. But the second part is very weak in my opinion. Although I have heard that people are praising the second act for how great the environment, puzzle's, and story of the act is, I do disagree. I felt like most of the act I was just wondering around wondering "Where tf am I supposed to go?" and I had to watch a lot of walkthroughs to find where I was supposed to go. The story of the second act was ok, and interesting to see the origins of Aperture and Glados, The third act was fine too, but I think I preferred the first act.

Overall you should buy this game, it's definitely worth it, but I felt like some parts of the game (especially the second act) could've been done much better than they turned out to be.

portal 2 ur mums house

This game saved my life.

I am 78.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

This game has coop and it is good to play with friends. Definetly recommend buying it when it is on sale.
